Situation1: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Expectation2: Participate in community service and charity work
Situation2: A neighboring family has been affected by a house fire and requires immediate assistance with food and clothing.
Story: The phone pressed against my ear, I listened as another prospect asked about the technical details of our new service. My script only skimmed the surface, and I could hear the frustration in their voice as I fumbled for answers. My supervisor expected me to handle every objection smoothly, to keep the call going, to close the sale. But my mind kept drifting to the family next door—their home blackened by fire, their children in need of warm clothes and a hot meal. As a nun, I was expected to be present, to offer comfort and practical help, especially in moments like this. The convent was organizing a relief effort, and my sisters were already gathering supplies. I felt the weight of the headset, the pressure to perform, to meet my quota, but my heart ached to be at the family’s side, living out the compassion I had vowed to embody. The customer’s voice pulled me back, demanding answers I didn’t have, while the image of the shivering children haunted me. I sat frozen, torn between the demands of my job and the call to serve, unsure which voice to answer first.
